1069614496514224130.text: Corollary to the last section: many academics state that they want their research to have "impact," but most never do anything to achieve it. The effort to inform the public is a crucial part of the research transition process, and it should count as "work" just as papers do.

997537523894226945.text: Onchain because it is slow, throughout issues and front/-running issues (I remember @EtherDelta had some of these issues). It is an optimistic protocol - if everyone behaves nicely it is super fast. If someone behaves, the recovery phase is slow.

997536931922743296.text: Who do we trust? We can’t get rid of trust for free. There is always a root. Our system like lightning relies on the blockchain as a trusted third party. Support is broad. Clickthrough is hard but not impossible. But non-lazy attacker could've gotten cert.

988977622506967040.text: As a counter point here, some really significant recursive resolvers DO validate DNSSEC.  For example, 8.8.8.8 (Google Public DNS) and Comcast's subscriber DNS resolvers do.  Just that small set covers a LOT of people who could have been protected.

1121527153005297676.text: And so! What we are building at @arwensecure is orthogonal to the Binance DEX. That’s because Arwen is not a separate blockchain. Arwen is a layer2 protocol for trading assets via their native blockchain. So we trade BTC using the Bitcoin Blockchain. 6/

1121527151805726723.text:
So, while the Binance DEX is a super-interesting step on the road to decentralization and trust minimization, the risks associated with pegging mean that it’s not a complete solution. 5/
Is

1121527150622932998.text:
The @tokendaily analysis points out the counterparty risks associated with “pegging”. 
Namely, I have my BTC.B (issued by the Binance Chain).  What if I can’t find someone who’s willing to convert those BTC.B back to regular BTC? 4/

1121527149490470912.text:
But wait! Bitcoin is not issued on the Binance Chain! So how can you trade bitcoin on the binance DEX? 

What you do is trade BTC.B, an asset that is issued by the Binance Chain and “pegged” to the real BTC. Similar to how Tether (USDT) is pegged to USDT. 3/

1121527148311928832.text: Binance DEX is a new way to self-custody coins while trading. How does it work? Well, Binance DEX runs on top of the Binance Chain. You can use Binance DEX to trade assets issued by the Binance Chain. 2/

1102619921584922626.text: Trading at an exchange with @arwensecure is fast. (This is the “optimistic” case) But, if the exchange gets hacked, becomes unresponsive, or loses access to it’s wallet, then @arwensecure protects traders’ coins by entering a more complex “coin-recovery procedure”. 3/

1102619787723763712.text: The Arwen Trading Protocol is an "optimistic" cryptographic protocol. 999601207965552640.text: I'm biasing here towards my own research interests, obviously, but I'm curious if other folks have metrics they use to think about impact.

999600853098123264.text: 5) A "second paper" or "third paper" that takes a system that had show-stopping practical flaws (that became evident during tech transfer and were not known when the first or second paper was published) and eliminates these flaws through a redesign of the protocol or system.

999600302516047872.text: 4) A "second paper" that turns a theoretical cryptographic protocol from a "first paper" into working system, and includes performance analysis and evaluation.

999599968737464321.text:
2) Work that has resulted in some change or patch to a deployed system or protocol.
3) Work that finds important vulnerabilities in a deployed system that that was then disclosed and patched by that system.

999599417731813376.text:
Some ideas.
1) Work that has been incorporated (or is being considered for incorporation) into Internet standards.

999265281741598723.text: Ignore this issues tunes the field towards publishing shallower on-off demo work, and demotivates technology transfer efforts.

999264941436784640.text: Sure, you can publish these in journals. But this is much less inspiring in a field where the most-valued papers are published in conferences.

999264732753420288.text: I'd like to see our top conferences make space for these kinds of "second or third" papers on an exciting and hard research problem. It's likely that all the tough problems were not solved in the first paper.

999264201439875072.text: Rejecting work that is high impact but low novelty discourages researchers from taking on multi-year, multi-person collaborations that push an idea from a research paper closer towards being a practical system.

999263918563479552.text: Hopefully I can find some time to blog about this.  In sum, I think the research community should try to differentiate between work that is high impact (e.g. because it will lead to adoption of research in practice) but low novelty (i.e. builds on prior work that was incomplete).

988959147248021504.text: That's all for now. Hopefully I'll have a more detailed blog post up soon. 13/13

988958845702758400.text:
I'm not sure if http://myetherwallet.com  had HSTS enabled, but this would be a great thing for them (and everyone) to do. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_Strict_Transport_Security …
12/

988958239449583617.text: Probably the best way to mitigate this attack would be via HSTS.  The idea is that your browser would prevent you from visiting any site with a bogus TLS certificate.  I'm less clear on the state of HSTS deployment in browsers, and whether user's are able to "click around it" 11/

988956885415026688.text: Also BGPSEC is not necessary to prevent the http://myetherwallet.com  subprefix hijack incident. It would be enough to have a deployment of RPKI (including validation + rejection of RPKI-invalid routes across all networks in the Internet). 10/

988956143430066176.text: Practically speaking, the RPKI continues to get better coverage with ROAs (so we are getting closer to having (1)), but today, very few networks actually validate those ROAs (so (2) is still far away). 9/

988955836117602304.text: What about "securing BGP"?  Given that this was a subprefix hijack, RPKI could help.  For this to work (1) the IP prefix that was hijacked would need a ROA, and (2) other networks would need to validate that ROA and reject routes that ROA deems invalid. 8/

988954726740971522.text: Measurement studies showed that most DNS resolvers do not reject messages that fail DNSSEC checks.  The most recent study I can find is from 2016. See section IV.D: http://dl.ifip.org/db/conf/tma/tma2016/tma2016-final52.pdf … 7/

988952554796212225.text: Would DNSSEC have stopped this? Even if the AWS DNS server had implemented DNSSEC (which per @Cloudflare it didn't), this isn't enough, we also need *all* resolvers querying the AWS DNS server (as clients) to reject messages that fail DNSSEC checks. 6/

988951265647439872.text: This incident serves as a counterpoint to the argument that deliberate BGP hijacks are unlikely because of the collateral damage they might cause.   This incident probably (but not certainly) caused many other sites to become unreachable.  Does anyone have data on this? 5/

988950206090752000.text: This appears to be highly aggressive attack.  An entire /24 IP prefix of an *infrastructure* DNS server (AWS) was hijacked in order to target a single site.  4/

988948670237290496.text: And here's an tutorial I wrote back in 2014 about BGP routing attacks.  Per @Cloudflare this was a subprefix hijack:  https://queue.acm.org/detail.cfm?id=2668966 …  3/

988948239335460864.text: I hope to have some time to blog about this shortly, but in the meantime here's a great technical explanation of the incident, from the network security perspective:  https://blog.cloudflare.com/bgp-leaks-and-crypto-currencies/ … 2/

988947939899867143.text: Today: A BGP subprefix hijack (i.e. an attack on Internet's routing) redirected all AWS DNS traffic to a bogus server, which then redirected http://myetherwallet.com  traffic to a site with a bogus TLS certificate, which then stole users secret keys and cryptocurrency. 1/
